SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces in the sheets of paper. If there is not sufficient space left to answer all the questions, please state to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Past: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Enjoy?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

My oldest brother came to Canada and told me there was a good place to settle. Someone at what time owns 160 acres of land. We would like a lot of land to live on.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

The relatives seemed to think it was OK for my brothers to go and homestead but what dad was mad to sell his home and go.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

We came by train to far as Kamloops

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Train and horse and wagon.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

The only incident was the long waits we had between trains. Some places we had to wait from one day to one day and a half for a train.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

We stayed at Kamloops then drove to our homestead. The next day Dad had to homestead for us.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Mearns Rd., which is 30 miles north of Kamloops.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

I have lived Kelowna twice. My last three years I've lived at Mearns Road at Mearns Road and still in very good condition around Norquay and still in very good condition.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

When a child and until I went to work in a sawmill machinery, brought grain, worked in a garage. Alone carpentry and now I farm again and am a carpenter.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Many people homesteaders stayed on the homesteads a short time then left. Most of them were bachelors. I think they were homesick or homesick. The most families proved up the homestead before they left.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

None moved out, but oh how many moved in. They came by wagon, by train, or car. They walked and most of them are still here. Some left during the war and came back again.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

I owned the first automobile a 1914 Ford.

My dad was the first settler in Norway district.

Ole Johnson built the 1st church.

McPherson built the 1st store.

Pranteburg school was the 1st school.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

The roads. More elevators so there's competition, our creamery, and hospital, and more fields, and now we own a car and a tractor. Better types of grain, our old seed were mostly a longer season grain, and with the opening of the country, we have less frosts.
